case_name: Indian Chemical Products Ltd. v. State of Orissa

facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 303 of 1963 was filed.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION- Civil Appeal No. 303 of 1963. Appeal from the judgment

facts.text: Appeal from judgment and order dated September 5, 1960 of Orissa High Court.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal from the judgment and order dated September 5, 1960 of the Orissa High Court in Appeal under Orissa High Court Order No. 4 of 1956.

facts.text: Indian Chemical Products, Ltd. incorporated on November 29, 1947 with registered offices in Baripada, Mayurbhanj and Calcutta.

anchor.surface_text: On November 29, 1947, the Indian Chemical Products, Ltd., a limited company, was incorporated having its registered offices in Baripada, Mayurbhanj and in the town of Calcutta.

facts.text: Authorised capital Rs. 25 lakhs divided into 25,000 shares of Rs. 100 each.

anchor.surface_text: Its authorised capital is Rs. 25 lakhs divided into 25,000 shares of Rs. 100 each. The company has seven share-holders.

facts.text: Maharaja of Mayurbhanj subscribed and paid for 7,500 shares.

anchor.surface_text: The Maharaja of Mayurbhanj subscribed and paid for 7,500 shares. The remaining six shareholders hold 150 shares only.

facts.text: State of Orissa claims shares vested in it by operation of law due to constitutional changes.

anchor.surface_text: The State of Orissa claims that by reason of the constitutional changes since the declaration of independence, all the shares held by the Maharaja of Mayurbhanj have vested in it by operation of law.

facts.text: State claims based also on formal instrument of transfer executed by Maharaja.

anchor.surface_text: The State also based its claim to the shares on a formal instrument of transfer executed by the Maharaja.

facts.text: On March 16, 1950, Government of Orissa lodged share scrip and transfer deed with company and requested changes in share register.

anchor.surface_text: On March 16, 1950, the Government of Orissa lodged the share scrip and the transfer deed with the company, and requested it to make the necessary changes in the share register.

facts.text: On May 16, 1953, board of directors refused to register the transfer.

anchor.surface_text: eventually on May 16, 1953, the board of directors of the company refused to register the transfer.

facts.text: On December 1, 1953, Sri S. K. Mandal requested company to record State as owner, company declined.

anchor.surface_text: On December, 1, 1953, Sri S. K. Mandal, attorney for the State of Orissa, requested the company to record the name of the State as the owner of the shares in the share register, but the company declined to do so.

facts.text: On February 9, 1955, State of Orissa filed application under s.38 Companies Act in Orissa High Court for rectification.

anchor.surface_text: On February 9, 1955, the State of Orissa filed an application under s. 38 of the Indian Companies Act, 1913 in the High Court of Orissa asking for rectification of the share register by inserting its name as the holder of the shares in place of the Maharaja.

facts.text: Company and Maharaja impleaded as respondents; contested by company only.

anchor.surface_text: The company and the Maharaja were impleaded as respondents. The application was contested by the company only.

facts.text: On November 22, 1956, Ray J. allowed the application.

anchor.surface_text: On November 22, .1956, Ray, J. allowed the application.

facts.text: On September 13, 1957, supplemental order directing notice of rectification.

anchor.surface_text: On September 13, 1957, he passed a supplemental order directing the filing of the notice of rectification with the Registrar within a fortnight.

facts.text: On September 5, 1960, Division Bench dismissed company appeal.

anchor.surface_text: On September 5, 1960, a Division Bench of the High Court dismissed the appeal preferred by the company.

facts.text: Courts held title to shares vested in State of Orissa by operation of law.

anchor.surface_text: Both courts concurrently held that 1 the title to the shares vested in the State of Orissa by operation of law 2 the, refusal of the board of directors to register the transfer was mala fide

facts.text: Refusal of board to register transfer was mala fide.

anchor.surface_text: 2 the, refusal of the board of directors to register the transfer was mala fide 3 the State of Orissa was entitled to rectification of the share register

facts.text: 7,500 shares held by Maharaja in capacity as ruler of Mayurbhanj.

anchor.surface_text: The courts below concurrently found that the 7,500 shares were held by the Maharaja in his capacity as ruler of the State of Mayurbhanj.

facts.text: On October 17, 1948, Maharaja signed merger agreement.

anchor.surface_text: On October 17, 1948, the Maharaja of Mayurbhanj signed an agreement for the merger of the State with the Dominion.

facts.text: By art.1, Maharaja ceded sovereignty as from November 9, 1948.

anchor.surface_text: By art. 1 of this agreement, the Maharaja completely ceded to the Dominion his sovereignty over the State of Mayurbhanj as from November 9, 1948.

facts.text: Public properties including 7,500 shares vested in Dominion from November 9, 1948.

anchor.surface_text: On and from November 9, 1948, as a necessary consequence of the cesser of sovereignty all the public properties of the State including the 7,500 shares in the company vested in the Dominion.

facts.text: States Merger (Governors' Provinces) Order, 1949 came into force on August 1, 1949.

anchor.surface_text: On August 1, 1949, the States Merger Governors Provinces Order, 1949 came into force,

facts.text: By certificate dated November 10, 1953, Government of India declared shares not held for central purposes.

anchor.surface_text: By a certificate dated November 10, 1953, the Government of India declared that the 7,500 shares were not held for central purposes.

facts.text: Company contends directors have power to refuse under art.11.

anchor.surface_text: The company contends that under its articles, the directors have the power to refuse the registration. It relies on art. 11, which reads-

facts.text: Courts held directors had no power to refuse registration of transfer by operation of law.

anchor.surface_text: The appellate Court also held that under the articles of association of the company the board of directors had no power to refuse registration of a transfer where the transfer was by operation of law.

facts.text: Board acted mala fide in refusing transfer deed.

anchor.surface_text: Even with regard to this claim, the Courts below concurrently held that the board of directors acted mala fide in refusing to register the transfer.

facts.text: On March 17, 1953, company assured Imperial Bank registration would be effected shortly.

anchor.surface_text: By its letter dated March 17, 1953, the company assured the Bank that the registration would be effected shortly.

facts.text: Appeal dismissed by Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: There is no merit in this appeal. The appeal is dismissed with costs.

On February 9, 1955, the State of Orissa filed an application under s. 38 of the Indian Companies Act, 1913 in the High Court of Orissa asking for rectification of the share register by inserting its name as the holder of the shares in place of the Maharaja.
the State of Orissa was entitled to rectification of the share register and a proper case for the exercise of the Courts jurisdiction under s. 38 of the Indian Companies Act, 1913 had been made out

concepts.interpretation: The Courts jurisdiction under S. 38 is, therefore, attracted. The High Court rightly ordered the rectification in the exercise of its summary powers under S. 38. The jurisdiction created by S. 38 is very beneficial and should be liberally exercised.

arguments.claim: Bentham Mills precedent supports distinction between transfer and transmission

anchor.surface_text: In In re. Bentham Mills Spinning Company 1 , James, L.J. said In Table A the word transmission is put in contradistinction to the word transfer. One means a transfer by the act of the parties, the other means transmission by devolution of law.

arguments.court_reasoning: Directly applies to Table A distinction.

holdings.text: By reason of these successive constitutional changes, the shares became vested in the State of Orissa. The State is the legal owner of the shares

anchor.surface_text: By reason of these successive constitutional changes, the shares became vested in the State of Orissa. The State is the legal owner of the shares and the directors of the company are bound to enter its name in the register of members, unless there is some restrictive provision in the articles authorising them to refuse the registration.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Merger agreement ceded sovereignty to Dominion on Nov 9 1948 vesting public properties including shares; delegation and States Merger Order s.5(1) vested in Orissa from Aug 1 1949 confirmed by certificate not for central purposes; Constitution integrated territory.

holdings.text: Under the articles, the directors had therefore no power to refuse registration of the devolution of title on the State of Orissa by operation of law in consequence of the constitutional changes.

anchor.surface_text: Under the articles, the directors had therefore no power to refuse registration of the devolution of title on the State of Orissa by operation of law in consequence of the constitutional changes.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Art 11 refers only to transfers by act of parties not transmission by operation of law; distinction in Table A regulations; Bentham Mills precedent; clause 22 limited to death/insolvency; strict construction of restrictive provision.

holdings.text: Article 11 refers to transfers. A devolution of title by operation of law is not within its purview. Being a restrictive provision, the article must be strictly construed.

anchor.surface_text: Article 11 refers to transfers. A devolution of title by operation of law is not within its purview. Being a restrictive provision, the article must be strictly construed. In the instant case, the title to the shares vested in the State of Orissa by operation of law, and the State did not require an instrument of transfer from the Maharaja to complete its title.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Table A distinguishes transfer (instrument by parties) from transmission (devolution by law); Art 11 limited to transfers; strict construction required.

holdings.text: the board of directors acted mala fide in refusing to register the transfer. This finding is amply supported by the materials on the record.

anchor.surface_text: Even with regard to this claim, the Courts below concurrently held that the board of directors acted mala fide in refusing to register the transfer. This finding is amply supported by the materials on the record.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Frivolous pretexts like stamp duty despite certificate; delay over 3 years; afterthought reliance on non-binding cl.6 proposal; assurance to bank then capricious refusal.

holdings.text: The power under Art. 11 to refuse registration of the transfer is a discretionary power. The directors must exercise this power reasonably and in good faith. The Court can control their discretion if they act capriciously or in bad faith.

anchor.surface_text: The power under Art. 11 to refuse registration of the transfer is a discretionary power. The directors must exercise this power reasonably and in good faith. The Court can control their discretion if they act capriciously or in bad faith.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Discretion not absolute; cannot use to coerce agreement or act capriciously; court controls abuse.

holdings.text: The Courts jurisdiction under S. 38 is, therefore, attracted. The High Court rightly ordered the rectification in the exercise of its summary powers under S. 38. The jurisdiction created by S. 38 is very beneficial and should be liberally exercised.

anchor.surface_text: The Courts jurisdiction under S. 38 is, therefore, attracted. The High Court rightly ordered the rectification in the exercise of its summary powers under S. 38. The jurisdiction created by S. 38 is very beneficial and should be liberally exercised.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Default in register: Maharaja ceased to be member, State owner omitted without sufficient cause; beneficial jurisdiction liberally exercised.

holdings.text: We cannot accept the contention that the petition was liable to be dismissed because the State of Orissa had asked for registration in the name of the Secretary, Finance Department.

anchor.surface_text: We cannot accept the contention that the petition was liable to be dismissed because the State of Orissa had asked for registration in the name of the Secretary, Finance Department. No such objection was taken by the company, although it had taken numerous other objections.

holdings.reasoning_summary: No prior objection raised despite opportunities; later letter explicitly requested State's name.

holdings.text: we express no opinion on the question whether such an article applies to an involuntary transfer of shares by a Court sale having regard to the provisions of O.21, r. 80 of the Code of Civil Procedure with regard to the execution of necessary documents of transfer.

anchor.surface_text: We may add that we express no opinion on the question whether such an article applies to an involuntary transfer of shares by a Court sale having regard to the provisions of O.21, r. 80 of the Code of Civil Procedure with regard to the execution of necessary documents of transfer.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Expressly reserved; not necessary for decision.

anchor.surface_text: By reason of these successive constitutional changes, the shares became vested in the State of Orissa. The State is the legal owner of the shares and the directors of the company are bound to enter its name in the register of members, unless there is some restrictive provision in the articles authorising them to refuse the registration.
The appeal is dismissed with companyts.

anchor.surface_text: Article 11 refers to transfers. A devolution of title by operation of law is not within its purview. Being a restrictive provision, the article must be strictly construed. In the instant case, the title to the shares vested in the State of Orissa by operation of law, and the State did not require an instrument of transfer from the Maharaja to complete its title.
The appeal is dismissed with companyts.

anchor.surface_text: Even with regard to this claim, the Courts below concurrently held that the board of directors acted mala fide in refusing to register the transfer. This finding is amply supported by the materials on the record.
The appeal is dismissed with companyts.

edges.explanation: Holding states directors must exercise discretionary power reasonably and in good faith, addressing the issue.

anchor.surface_text: The power under Art. 11 to refuse registration of the transfer is a discretionary power. The directors must exercise this power reasonably and in good faith. The Court can control their discretion if they act capriciously or in bad faith.
The appeal is dismissed with companyts.
rcised. We see numberreason why the Court should deny the applicant relief under S. 38. The directors of the appellant companypany on the most frivolo

edges.explanation: Holding that jurisdiction under s.38 attracted addresses the issue of entitlement to rectification under s.38.

anchor.surface_text: The Courts jurisdiction under S. 38 is, therefore, attracted. The High Court rightly ordered the rectification in the exercise of its summary powers under S. 38. The jurisdiction created by S. 38 is very beneficial and should be liberally exercised.
The appeal is dismissed with companyts.

We cannot accept the contention that the petition was liable to be dismissed because the State of Orissa had asked for registration in the name of the Secretary, Finance Department. No such objection was taken by the company, although it had taken numerous other objections.
The appeal is dismissed with companyts.
